medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Extruded herniated disc, left L5-S1. 2. Left S1 radiculopathy (acute). 3. Morbid obesity. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Extruded herniated disc, left L5-S1. 2. Left S1 radiculopathy (acute). 3. Morbid obesity. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Microscopic lumbar discectomy, left L5-S1. ANESTHESIA: General. COMPLICATIONS: None. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 50 cc. HISTORY: This is a 40-year-old female with severe intractable left leg pain from a large extruded herniated disc at L5-S1. She has been dealing with these symptoms for greater than three months. She comes to my office with severe pain, left my office and reported to the Emergency Room where she was admitted for pain control one day before surgery. I have discussed the MRI findings with the patient and the potential risks and complications. She was scheduled to go to surgery through my office, but because of her severe symptoms, she was unable to keep that appointment and reported right to the Emergency Room. We discussed the diagnosis and the operative procedure in detail. I have reviewed the potential risks and complications and she had agreed to proceed with the surgery. Due to the patient's weight which exceeds 340 lb, there was some concern about her operative table being able to support her weight and also my standard microlumbar discectomy incision is not ________ in this situation just because of the enormous size of the patient's back and abdomen and I have discussed this with her. She is aware that she will have a much larger incision than what is standard and has agreed to accept this. OPERATIVE PROCEDURE: The patient was taken to OR #5 at ABCD General Hospital. While in the hospital gurney, Department of Anesthesia administered general anesthetic, endotracheal intubation was followed. A Jackson table was prepared for the patient and was reinforced replacing struts under table to prevent the table from collapsing. The table reportedly does have a limit of 500 lb, but the table has never been stressed above 275 lb. Once the table was reinforced, the patient was carefully rolled in a prone position on the Jackson table with the bony prominences being well padded. A marker was placed in from the back at this time and an x-ray was obtained for incision localization. The back is now prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A midline incision was made over the L5-S1 disc space taking through subcutaneous tissue sharply with a #10 Bard-Parker scalpel. The lumbar dorsal fascia was then encountered and incised to the left of midline. In the subperiosteal fashion, the musculature was elevated off the lamina at L5 and S1 after facet joint, but not disturbing the capsule. A second marker was now placed and an intraoperative x-ray confirms our location at the L5-S1 disc space. The microscope was brought into the field at this point and the remainder of the procedure done with microscopic visualization and illumination. A high speed drill was used to perform a laminotomy by removing small portion of the superior edge of the S1 lamina and the inferior edge of the L5 lamina. Ligaments and fragments were encountered and removed at this time. The epidural space was now encountered. The S1 nerve root was now visualized and found to be displaced dorsally as a result of a large disc herniation while the nerve was carefully protected with a Penfield. A small stab incision was made into the disc fragment and probably a large portion of disc extrudes from the opening. This disc fragment was removed and the nerve root was much more supple, it was carefully retracted. The nerve root was now retracted and using a series of downgoing curettes, additional disc material was removed from around the disc space and from behind the body of S1 and L5. At this point, all disc fragments were removed from the epidural space. Murphy ball was passed anterior to the thecal sac in the epidural space and there was no additional compression that I can identify. The disc space was now encountered and loose disc fragments were removed from within the disc space. The disc space was then irrigated. The nerve root was then reassessed and found to be quite supple. At this point, the Murphy ball was passed into the foramen of L5 and this was patent and also into the foramen of S1 by passing ventral and dorsal to the nerve root and there were no obstructions in the passage of the device. At this point, the wound was irrigated copiously and suctioned dry. Gelfoam was used to cover the epidural space. The retractors were removed at this point. The fascia was reapproximated with #1 Vicryl suture, subcutaneous tissue with #2-0 Vicryl suture and Steri-Strips for curved incision. The patient was transferred to the hospital gurney in supine position and extubated by Anesthesia, subsequently transferred to Postanesthesia Care Unit in stable condition.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnoses:**  
1. A large herniated disc that has pushed out of place at the left L5‑S1 level of the spine.  
2. Sudden left leg pain caused by pressure on the left S1 nerve root.  
3. Extremely high body weight (morbid obesity).

**Post‑operative diagnoses:**  
Same as pre‑operative.

**Procedure performed:**  
Microscopic removal of the herniated disc at the left L5‑S1 level.

**Anesthesia:**  
General anesthesia (the patient was fully asleep).

**Complications:**  
None.

**Estimated blood loss:**  
About 50 milliliters (about 1 ounce).

**History:**  
The patient is a 40‑year‑old woman who has had severe, unrelenting pain in her left leg for more than three months because of a large herniated disc at L5‑S1. She first came to the doctor’s office, was taken to the emergency room for pain control, and was admitted one day before surgery. The doctor explained the MRI results, the risks and possible complications of surgery, and the plan for the operation. The patient agreed to have the surgery. Because she weighs more than 340 pounds, the doctor had to make sure the operating table could support her weight and explained that the incision would be larger than usual. She understood and accepted this.

**Operative procedure:**  
The patient was taken to operating room #5 at ABCD General Hospital. While on the hospital gurney, the anesthesia team gave her general anesthesia and intubated her (placed a breathing tube). A special operating table (Jackson table) was prepared and reinforced with extra supports because the table’s normal limit is 500 pounds, but it had never been used for more than 275 pounds. After the table was reinforced, the patient was carefully turned onto her stomach (prone) on the table, with padding under bony areas. A marker was placed on her back and an X‑ray was taken to confirm the correct spot for the incision. The back was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. A midline cut was made over the L5‑S1 disc space using a sharp #10 scalpel. The outer layer of the back (dorsal fascia) was cut to the left of the midline. The muscles were lifted off the bone (lamina) at L5 and S1, taking care not to disturb the joint capsule. A second marker was placed and another X‑ray confirmed the location. A microscope was brought in, and the rest of the work was done under microscopic vision. A high‑speed drill removed a small piece of the upper edge of the S1 lamina and the lower edge of the L5 lamina (laminotomy). Ligaments and disc fragments were removed. The epidural space (area around the spinal cord) was reached. The left S1 nerve root was seen, displaced upward by the large disc herniation, and was protected with a Penfield instrument. A small cut was made into the disc fragment, and a large portion of the disc was removed. The nerve root became more flexible, and it was gently retracted. Using curettes, more disc material was removed from around the disc space and behind the bodies of S1 and L5. All disc fragments were cleared from the epidural space. A small “Murphy ball” was passed in front of the thecal sac (the covering of the spinal cord) in the epidural space; no extra compression was found. Loose disc pieces inside the disc space were removed, and the space was irrigated (washed). The nerve root was checked again and was very flexible. The Murphy ball was then passed into the L5 foramen (opening) and then into the S1 foramen, moving around the nerve root without obstruction. The wound was washed thoroughly and suctioned dry. Gelfoam was used to cover the epidural space. Retractors were removed. The outer layer of tissue (fascia) was stitched together with #1 Vicryl sutures, the subcutaneous tissue with #2‑0 Vicryl sutures, and Steri‑Strips were applied to the curved incision. The patient was moved onto a hospital gurney in the supine position, the breathing tube was removed by anesthesia, and she was transferred to the Post‑Anesthesia Care Unit in stable condition.
